title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [2 may 1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [2 May 1867]
text: Brooklyn3 May '67thursdayThursday eveningDear Walti received your letter yesterday with the 5 dldollars and it was very acceptable well walt there is so much to write about really i dontdon't know how to begin well to commence george is getting along pretty well but very little upsets him he has the headachheadache and is not very strong but he goes down town almost every day but gets tired toward night but i think he will get along very well) now i must tell you walt how we are getting along with our troubles matty has sold nearly all her things except her carpets and beds and spent the money as fast as it came in for clothes to go in the country for many things she got more than she gave for her chickinschickens she got 18 dlsdollars and all she sold yeryvery well mr bullard owes her 100) hundred which mrs Beecher is responcibleresponsible for and the house is all in confusion and a dresmakerdressmaker here till saturdaySaturday and they are here cleaning and to morrowtomorrow mat and the children and dresmakeredressmaker moves up with me george says i must try to have patience but I dontdon't know how i can stand it very long never was any thing managed so before her going off to masons to stay is so absurd and we must move O walt if they was away i should get a place and move but i dontdon't know how to get a place for them all she sold all her things and boxed up all her beds and matt has had so much money to spend but then i wontwon't say any more the bullards is coming next tuesdayTuesday davis has got back from worsterWorcester mat says he wants me to get out and not be hanging on) they want to hire the piano he is having the house all put in thouroughthorough order at the park expenceexpense)well Walt i am done with that part now i must tell you the other side George is not going to put a house on the putmanPutnam avenavenue lot but will sell it for what it will fetch back of the blacksmiths shop they have put a carpenters shop so he and smith went to look at it the other day and decided not to build on it at all he and smith went to look at some lots yesterday they liked very much on the corner of tomkinsTompkins avenuavenue and lafaetteLafayette st george says it is very fine but it is a plot and the price is 3000 dollardollars cash the turners has the selling of it he has gone again to day to see what they can doodo george says he knows you would like it it is within one block of the decalbDeKalb ave cars if they could get it they would build a number of smalishsmallish houses he says the neigberhoodneighborhood is very good but he is afraid they cantcan't manage to get it so when i next write i dontdon't know what the progress will be but Walt you must not be alarmed if you hear we have boughbought the lickfieldlitchfield property or maybeemaybe some of the shantysshanties on the park i often think if i had a shanty i could be contented where i could be at peace and not have to movegood bie Walter deari will try to take things coolly as you advise i will write when we get a place i thought we would get a second story there seems to be quite a number to rent Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [2 May 1867]
